DOC.HEAD: China To Amend Joint Venture Law
DOC.TEXT: China's legislature, in a bid to restore confidence among businesses and investors, has proposed changing a law governing joint ventures with foreign firms. The proposed amendments include guarantees that the government will not nationalize or requisition joint ventures, the official media reported Thursday. The changes also stipulate that partners in a joint venture may choose the chairman and vice chairman of their operation. Under current law, the chairman must come from the Chinese side of the partnership. The new law would not require partners to set a specific time for the length of their contract. Previously all joint ventures were for fixed periods, often 20 or 30 years. Some 8,000 joint ventures have been established since China opened its doors 10 years ago, and foreign investors have provided about $14 billion for business ventures. Chinese leaders have been trying to convince potential investors that the investment climate remains favorable despite the political turmoil of the pro-democracy movement and a tough government austerity program that has stopped implementation of new economic reforms. Foreign businessmen are concerned that their independence will be limited and that the current conservative atmosphere will mean more political interference in their operations. The draft amendments to the joint venture law are being discussed at an ongoing meeting of the National People's Congress Standing Committee. They are expected to be passed when the NPC, China's parliament, holds its annual session next spring.
